title: 105_hr3497
content: The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" establishes individual investment accounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" allows individuals to deduct cash contributions to individual investment accounts established for their benefit. An individual investment account is a trust created in the US for the exclusive benefit of an individual, with specific requirements for contributions and trustee qualifications. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" allows individuals to deduct cash contributions to individual investment accounts established for their benefit. Contributions must be made by the last day of the taxable year. Trust assets cannot be invested in collectibles and must not be commingled with other property. Distributions are subject to specific tax treatment. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" allows deductions for cash contributions to individual investment accounts. Distributions are taxed unless used for qualified 1st-time homebuyer expenses within 120 days. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" allows deductions for cash contributions to individual investment accounts. Qualified 1st-time homebuyer distributions for a principal residence are limited to $20,000. The basis of the residence is reduced by the distribution amount. Transferring account interests incident to divorce is allowed without tax implications. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" allows deductions for cash contributions to individual investment accounts. Transferring account interests incident to divorce is allowed without tax implications. Individual investment accounts are exempt from taxation unless they cease to qualify as such. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" allows deductions for cash contributions to individual investment accounts. If an individual engages in a prohibited transaction under section 4975, the account will lose its exemption and be treated as distributing all its assets. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" allows deductions for cash contributions to individual investment accounts. If an individual uses the account as security for a loan during the taxable year, that portion is treated as distributed to the individual. Rollover contributions are not subject to subsection (c)(1) if the amount is paid into another account. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" allows deductions for cash contributions to individual investment accounts. Rollover contributions are not subject to subsection (c)(1) if the amount is paid into another account within 60 days. Cost-of-Living Adjustment increases the $20,000 amount in subsection (c)(2)(B) for taxable years after 1998. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" allows deductions for cash contributions to individual investment accounts. Rounding rules apply to dollar amounts not multiples of $10. Custodial accounts are treated as trusts if held by a bank or person meeting requirements. The custodian of such accounts is treated as the trustee. The trustee of an individual investment account must report account activities to the Secretary and the account holder as required by regulations. Deductions for individual investment account contributions are allowed in arriving at adjusted gross income. Individual investment accounts are exempt from estate tax under section 222. Additionally, a new section 2047 is inserted after section 2045 in the Internal Revenue Code. "Individual investment accounts are exempt from estate tax under section 222. A new section 2047 is inserted after section 2045 in the Internal Revenue Code." Individual investment accounts are excluded from the gross estate value and are exempt from estate tax under section 222. Section 1014 does not apply to these accounts. Additionally, a special rule exempts individuals from tax on prohibited transactions concerning their individual investment accounts. Individual investment accounts are excluded from the gross estate value and are exempt from estate tax under section 222. Section 1014 does not apply to these accounts. A new subparagraph is added to address failure to provide reports on individual investment accounts under section 6693(a) of the Code. The amendment to section 1016 of the Code adjusts the basis of a residence acquired with funds from an individual investment account. Clerical amendments are made to the table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1. The table of sections for part III of subchapter A of chapter 11 of the Code is amended to include new items related to individual investment accounts and disclaimers. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years starting after December 31, 1997.
